title: Mourning Beads
creator: Once-known Asmat creator
description: Necklaces made of coix seeds (Job's Tears) are worn by some Indigenous women in mourning in Papau. Widows may wear up to 365 necklaces at the start of the mourning period--removing one necklace each day for a year--after which they are free to remarry.
subject: Papau;necklace;coix
source: McClung Museum, gift of Jane Gray Buchanan and Joel R. Buchanan

title: Eye Beads
creator: Unknown Manufacturer
description: The glass beads on this necklace were intentionally crafted to look like eyes. In some Islamic traditions, the beads are worn or carried as amulets to protect against the evil eye--the belief that looking at a person with envy can cause them misfortune.
subject: Necklace;glass;Islam
source: McClung Museum, gift of Mrs. Catherine Ann Taylor Miller

title: Prayers & Blessings
creator: Osti, Jane
description: This vessel of red earthenware clay was built using the traditional Cherokee coil method of hand building. The surface is incised and stone burnished. I used other characteristics of Cherokee Pottery that include the addition of nodes and notching on the rim. The incised spiral was one of the most often used designs in Southeastern pottery. The symbolism of the spiral on this pottery represents prayers going up to the Creator and blessings coming down from the Creator.
subject: Cherokee;pottery;redclay
location: Cherokee Nation, Tahlequah, Oklahoma, United States of America

title: Satta Asaala (Coushatta Longleaf Pine Needle Turtle Effigy Basket)
creator: Alfaro, Lucia
description: My body of work exemplifies ancestral teachings, allowing me to honor those before me, and accompanies two aspects of our Coushatta Creation Story. I am inspired and influenced by those who lived during extreme hardships and adversity. Using their encouraging words and positive mentorship, I learned humbleness, gratefulness, respect, and perseverance. I have a desire for those around me to succeed and hope to inspire others as I have been inspired. Blessed with my traditional Coushatta upbringing, I continue balancing my life and work with modern-day living and will forever be honored, humbled, and appreciative.
subject: Coushatta;basket;pine
location: Koasati Territory, Elton, Louisiana, United States of America
